source: Yale University/George Mason University Climate Change in the American Mind Survey, November 2014
survey_by: Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication
question: Assuming global warming is happening, do you think it is caused mostly by human activities, caused mostly by natural changes in the environment, or none of the above because global warming isn't happening?
url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=environment&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication&studydate=01-JAN-34&sample=1275&qstn_list=&qstnid=1856214&qa_list=&qstn_id4=1856214&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332541&archno=&keywordDisplay=
description:
Survey by Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, October 17 - October 28, 2014 and based on   1,275 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Funding was provided by the 11th Hour Project, the Energy Foundation, the Grantham Foundation, and the V.K. Rasmussen Foundation. [USKN.111814CC.R04] (View Citation)
Topics: ENVIRONMENT
Formal Citation
Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication. Yale University/George Mason University Climate Change in the American Mind Survey,
Oct, 2014 [survey question]. USKN.111814CC.R04. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-15-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Caused  mostly by human activities': ' 50%', 'Caused mostly by natural changes in the environment': ' 32%', "None of the above because global warming isn't happening": '  9%', 'Other': '  9%'}

source: Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey, March 2017
question: What do you think are the three more important problems facing this country today? Please select which three of these are the most important....Abortion, national debt, environment and climate change, gay rights, gun control, health care, immigration, poverty, income inequality, unemployment, economic growth, military strength, morality and religion in society, racism, Social Security, taxes, women's rights, crime, foreign policy, education, terrorism and homeland security, or policy brutality
description:
Survey by Associated Press, Black Youth Project.
Methodology: Conducted by AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, February 16 - March 6, 2017 and based on   1,833 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult age 18-30. 1705 respondents were interviewed online, and 128 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month. [USAP.031817N.R07A] (View Citation)
Topics: PROBLEMS
Formal Citation
Associated Press, Black Youth Project. Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey,
Feb, 2017 [survey question]. USAP.031817N.R07A. AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-15-2017.

The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.

source: Associated Press-NORC Attitudes on Climate Change Survey, November 2015
question: Do you think global warming is caused entirely by human activities, caused mostly by human activities, caused about equally by human activities and natural changes in the environment, or caused entirely by natural changes in the environment?
description:
DOWNLOAD DATASET
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, October 15 - October 18, 2015 and based on   1,058 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult. 753 respondents were interviewed online, and 305 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC?s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States. [USAP.111715N.R10] (View Citation)
Topics: ENVIRONMENT
Dataset: USAPNORC2015-1018
Formal Citation

Oct, 2015 [survey question]. USAP.111715N.R10. AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-15-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Caused entirely by human activities': ' 12%', 'Caused mostly by human activities': ' 39%', 'Caused about equally by human activities and natural changes in the environment': ' 35%', 'Caused mostly by natural changes in the environment': '  7%', 'Caused entirely by natural changes in the environment': '  3%', 'Not sure': '  3%', 'Refused': '  *'}

source: Associated Press-NORC Attitudes on Climate Change Survey, December 2014
survey_by: Associated Press, National Opinion Research Center, Yale University School of Forestry & Environmental Studies
question: Do you think global warming is caused entirely by human activities, caused mostly by human activities, caused about equally by human activities and natural changes in the environment, caused mostly by natural changes in the environment, or caused entirely by natural changes in the environment?
url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=environment&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Associated Press, National Opinion Research Center, Yale University School of Forestry & Environmental Studies&studydate=01-JAN-34&sample=1578&qstn_list=&qstnid=1857946&qa_list=&qstn_id4=1857946&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332541&archno=&keywordDisplay=
description:
Survey by Associated Press, National Opinion Research Center, Yale University School of Forestry & Environmental Studies.
Methodology: Conducted by AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, November 20 - December 1, 2014 and based on   1,578 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.121214N.R26] (View Citation)
Topics: ENVIRONMENT
Formal Citation

Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-15-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.

url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=environment&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication&studydate=01-JAN-34&sample=1266&qstn_list=&qstnid=1898488&qa_list=&qstn_id4=1898488&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332541&archno=&keywordDisplay=
description:
Survey by Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, May 18 - June 6, 2017 and based on   1,266 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to 'self-select' into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Funding was provided by the 11th Hour Project, the Energy Foundation, the Grantham Foundation, and the MacArthur Foundation. [USKN.070517CC.R04] (View Citation)

source: Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey, December 2016
question: Which of the following issues are the most important to you in terms of choosing which (2016)political candidate you will support? Select up to three issues....Abortion, national debt, environment ad climate change, gay rights, gun control, health care, immigration, poverty, income inequality, unemployment, economic growth, military strength, morality and religion in society, racism, social security, taxes, women's rights, crime, foreign policy, education, terrorism and homeland security, police brutality
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, October 20 - November 3, 2016 and based on   1,843 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult age 18-30. 1751 respondents were interviewed online, and 92 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month [USAP.120616N.R10A] (View Citation)
Topics: PROBLEMS VOTE FOR PRESIDENT
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey,
Oct, 2016 [survey question]. USAP.120616N.R10A. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-15-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Abortion': '  8%', 'National debt': ' 15%', 'Environment and climate change': ' 15%', 'Gay rights': '  6%', 'Gun control': ' 14%', 'Health care': ' 22%', 'Immigration': ' 16%', 'Poverty': ' 12%', 'Income inequality': ' 15%', 'Unemployment': ' 12%', 'Economic growth': ' 22%', 'Military strength': '  4%', 'Morality and religion in society': '  5%', 'Racism': ' 17%', 'Social Security': '  4%', 'Taxes': ' 15%', "Women's rights": ' 10%', 'Crime': '  8%', 'Foreign policy': ' 11%', 'Education': ' 28%', 'Terrorism and homeland security': ' 19%', 'Police brutality': '  8%', 'Refused': '  1%'}

description:
Survey by Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, September 30 - October 19, 2015 and based on   1,330 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Funding was provided by the 11th Hour Project, the Energy Foundation, the Grantham Foundation, and the V.K. Rasmussen Foundation. [USKN.112015CC.R09F] (View Citation)
Topics: ENVIRONMENT

source: Associated Press-NORC Priorities for 2017 Survey, January 2017
question: For each of these problems that you mentioned, how much effort would you like the federal government to devote to solving this problem in the year 2017?...No effort at all, only a little effort, a moderate amount of effort, a lot of effort, a great deal of effort...Environment/Climate change
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, December 14 - December 19, 2016 and based on   1,017 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult. 846 respondents were interviewed online, and 171 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month [USAP.011817N.R03A] (View Citation)
Topics: PROBLEMS GOVERNMENT ENVIRONMENT
Formal Citation

Center for Public Opinion Research.

url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=environment&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=01/01/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication&studydate=01-JAN-34&sample=1004&qstn_list=&qstnid=1879775&qa_list=&qstn_id4=1879775&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332541&archno=&keywordDisplay=
description:
Survey by Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, March 18 - March 31, 2016 and based on   1,004 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to 'self-select' into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Funding was provided by the 11th Hour Project, the Energy Foundation, the Grantham Foundation, and the MacArthur Foundation. [USKN.050416CC.R02] (View Citation)

source: Associated Press-NORC Attitudes on Climate Change Survey, June 2017
question: Do you think climate change is caused entirely by human activities, caused mostly by human activities, caused about equally by human activities and natural changes in the environment, caused mostly by natural changes in the environment, or caused entirely by natural changes in the environment?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, June 8 - June 11, 2017 and based on   1,068 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult. 813 respondents were interviewed online, and 255 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States. [USAP.062017N.R05] (View Citation)

source: Associated Press-NORC Priorities for 2017 Survey, January 2017
question: How confident are you in the ability of the federal government to make progress on this problem in 2017?...Not at all confident, slightly confident, moderately confident, very confident, extremely confident...Environment/Climate change
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, December 14 - December 19, 2016 and based on   1,017 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult. 846 respondents were interviewed online, and 171 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month [USAP.011817N.R04A] (View Citation)

question: (Please rank these three problems facing this country today in order of their importance to you....Abortion, national debt, environment and climate change, gay rights, gun control, health care, immigration, poverty, income inequality, unemployment, economic growth, military strength, morality and religion in society, racism, Social Security, taxes, women's rights, crime, foreign policy, education, terrorism and homeland security, police brutality)...Second most important issue
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, August 1 - August 14, 2016 and based on   1,958 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult age 18-30. 1801 respondents were interviewed online, and 157 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States. 45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month [USAP.083116N.R10B2] (View Citation)

description:
Survey by Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, March 18 - March 31, 2016 and based on   1,004 online interviews. Sample: National registered voters. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to 'self-select' into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Funding was provided by the 11th Hour Project, the Energy Foundation, the Grantham Foundation, and the V.K. Rasmussen Foundation. [USKN.042516CC.R06L] (View Citation)

source: New York Times/Stanford University Poll, January 2015
topic: ELECTIONS CONGRESS VOTE FOR PRESIDENT ENVIRONMENT ENERGY ECONOMICS
question: Next, I will read you a statement that could be made by someone who wants to be a United States Senator or President of the United States. Here is the statement: 'I believe that global warming has been happening for the past 100 years, mainly because we have been burning fossil fuels and putting out greenhouse gasses. Now is the time for us to be using new forms of energy that are made in America and will be renewable forever. We can manufacture better cars that use less gasoline and build better appliances that use less electricity. We need to transform the outdated ways of generating energy into new ones that create jobs and entire industries, and stop the damage we've been doing to the environment.' If a candidate says this, would this make you more likely to vote for this candidate, less likely to vote for this candidate, or would it not affect how likely you would be to vote for this candidate?

source: CAP Energy Voters Poll, January 2015
sample: National likely voters including an oversample of Hispanics
question: Supporters of the Republican approach say that the best way to advance America's energy independence is to take full advantage of the abundant oil, gas, and coal resources already in the United States. They say we need to let the free market and the public's preferences determine which energy sources succeed by reducing regulations on the development of traditional energy resources and ending government subsidies for alternative energy ventures that often fail. Opponents say the Republican approach is not a balanced one because it will harm the environment and increase American dependence on non-renewable and dirty energy sources. The Republican plan calls for more drilling in American oceans, national forests, and public lands, reducing protections against air and water pollution, and will increase carbon pollution that scientists say is responsible for climate change. Who do you agree with more--supporters of the Republicans' approach or opponents of the Republicans' approach?

description:
Survey by Associated Press, National Opinion Research Center, Yale University School of Forestry & Environmental Studies.
Methodology: Conducted by AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, November 20 - December 1, 2014 and based on   1,578 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.121214N.R34D] (View Citation)
Topics: ENERGY ENVIRONMENT MOOD
Formal Citation
Associated Press, National Opinion Research Center, Yale University School of Forestry & Environmental Studies. Associated Press-NORC Attitudes on Climate Change Survey,
Nov, 2014 [survey question]. USAP.121214N.R34D. AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-15-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.

description:

Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, April 11 - April 24, 2014 and based on     860 online interviews. Sample: National registered voters. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed. A combination of random digit dialing (RDD) and address-based sampling (ABS) methodologies have been used to recruit panel members (in 2009 KnowledgePanel switched its sampling methodology for recruiting panel members from RDD to ABS). The panel comprises households with landlines and cellular phones, including those only with cell phones, and those without a phone. source: Associated Press-NORC America's Priorities and Outlook Survey, January 2014
survey_by: Associated Press, National Opinion Research Center
question: (For each of these problems that you mentioned, how confident are you that the federal government can make real progress in solving that issue in 2014?...Not at all confident, slightly confident, moderately confident, very confident, extremely confident)...Environment/climate change
description:
DOWNLOAD DATASET
ANALYZE DATASET
Survey by Associated Press, National Opinion Research Center.
Methodology: Conducted by AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, December 12 - December 16, 2013 and based on   1,141 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to 'self-select' into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.010214N.R04F] (View Citation)
Topics: PROBLEMS GOVERNMENT ENVIRONMENT
Dataset: USAPNORC2013-12

For Bill Smith, a NY (New York)fireman who lost his home to the storm, 'This is a real wake-up call.  For too long we've been burning fossil fuels without regard for the environment.  Now climate change is here and it's real.  And Sandy is just a taste of what's to come if we don't change our ways.  Lawmakers in Washington need to finally get serious about climate policy.' question: As you may know, hydraulic fracturing or 'fracking' is a process used to develop deposits of natural gas recently discovered in many regions of America.  Environmentalists and some residents living near drilling operations worry that fracking can contaminate drinking water sources and worsen climate change.  The oil and natural gas industry maintains the process is safe and can create jobs and promote energy independence.  Which of the following comes closest to your view of what the federal government should do on this issue?...Ban fracking altogether because it's not safe for the environment.  Increase regulation of fracking to protect the environment, but not ban it.  Reduce regulation of fracking to encourage more natural gas production.

question: Now I am going to read you another pair of statements.  First statement: When it comes to energy and gas prices.  Barack Obama says foreign oil imports are costing our economy 1.4 billion dollars a day.  The recent increase in gas prices makes it plain that we cannot be held hostage by oil companies any longer.  He will invest $150 billion in clean, renewable energy, including bio-fuels to end the oil monopoly, and increase fuel standards further for American cars and trucks.  He strongly opposes lifting the limit on off-shore oil drilling saying it will do little to reduce the price of gas and is not worth the environmental cost.  Second statement:  John McCain says we need to invest more in alternative fuels and conserve more.  This is not only good for the country, but for the environment, and he led the effort in the US (United States)Senate for a comprehensive plan to reduce global warming.  But he also says that we need more domestic production of oil and has proposed lifting the federal ban on off-shore oil drilling to help reduce our dependence on foreign oil and stop sending money to countries friendly to terrorists.  Which statement comes closer to your own view?  (If First/Second statement, ask:)(Do you feel that way strongly or not so strongly?)
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, June 22 - June 25, 2008 and based on   2,008 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters. Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2008 election. [USGREEN.08DCJUN22.R097] (View Citation)

source: Coal, Energy Security, and Climate Change Survey, June 2008
survey_by: American Solutions for Winning the Future
question: I am now going to read you the opinions of two people--I will call them Smith and Jones.  Please tell me which one you agree with more.  Smith believes the US (United States)should increase its use of coal because it is a domestically available energy source and is less expensive than imported foreign oil.  Also, new technologies have dramatically reduced emissions from burning coal and made it much less harmful to the environment.  Jones believes the US should not increase its use of coal even though it is a less expensive, domestically available energy source, because burning coal is still a big contributor to carbon emissions and air pollution. (If Smith/Jones, ask:)And do you strongly agree with Smith/Jones or somewhat agree with Smith/Jones?
